author: ctrlaltdeleteracism
body:
# Your daily WSB history fact:

**Hoplites** (WSB members) were citizen-soldiers of Ancient Greek city-states (Reddit) who were primarily armed with spears (buy) and shields (hold). Hoplite soldiers utilized the phalanx formation to be effective in war with fewer soldiers (wsb vs. hedge funds). The formation discouraged the soldiers from acting alone, for this would compromise the formation and minimize its strengths (ape strong together). The hoplites were primarily represented by free citizens – propertied farmers and artisans – who were able to afford a linen armour or a bronze armour suit and weapons (stimulus check and ~~robinhood~~ Fidelity account). Most hoplites were not professional soldiers and often lacked sufficient military training (we aren't so bright guys, it's ok tho). Some states maintained a small elite professional unit, known as the *epilektoi* ("chosen") since they were picked from the regular citizen infantry (DFV). These existed at times in Athens, Argos, Thebes, and Syracuse, among others (Wild ronamarkets). 

&#x200B;

History is important. Now lets go out and make some.

author: royalsanguine
body:
Fidelity is VERY stingy about approving above level 1. I got approved for level 1 and resubmitted an application for level 2 and got approved for level 2 after the 2nd try. all in all took about 3.5 weeks.

They also charge 0.65cents per contract so you're losing money on every purchase which just means your options have to move that much more before you get a net profit.

use Fidelity and TD for legit stock trading and setting up a Roth IRA for your retirement fund but just use RH for yolo option plays. as much as people shit on RH in this sub there's no better alternative right now that's not webull and i'm not willing to go over a chinese owned company regardless of where they're "based".

author: MushyWasHere
body:
New trader here. I am starting to pick up on a trend: any time I read about a stock on Reddit, it's only *after* it has already spiked; i.e., it's too late to make a substantial profit, and likely to crash back down and make a bagholder out of me. Any tickers I have bought in on, I have sold back out of again very quickly before I could lose more than a pittance. Two months ago the idea of investing had never crossed my mind. Now I think I'm starting to learn how it works.

As I search for stocks and do my DD, I feel like I'm walking through a carnival full of carnies trying to swindle me. All of the financial sites try to drown me in nonsense, ads and disinformation. They only want to use me and leave me holding the bag. Unfortunately, I'm not finding much more potential in Reddit, either--these investing subs are pumped with tickers that have already made shareholders a massive profit... I'm not looking to buy at the top of a spike, or even at a subsequent median.

Recently, I've stopped looking for stocks that are on the rise, and am instead looking for ones that have just crashed.

However, it feels like I'm being restricted in terms of the stocks I can "see." **All** of the NYSE and NASDAQ tickers listed on the pennystock scanner sites are greater than .50... Yet most of them were worth much, much less than that just a few weeks ago. Obviously by the time they're listed for me to see, someone has already made a massive profit off them. It's as if they *hide* the names of tickers that are currently bottomed out.

Naturally, I started looking into OTC tickers, and got very excited about some of them. Then when I attempted to use my Fidelity account to pick up shares in some OTC stocks, they prevented me from buying 90% of the tickers I tried. They cite them "being a big risk," etc... I'm frustrated by that. I know they're a risk, but I'm buying them at an all-time low, you mother-f\*\*kers. I stand to lose very little, and make a lot. I don't think I'm being "protected" by Fidelity, I think I'm being cheated from some fat gains.

&#x200B;

That said, which brokers do you recommend for unlimited access to OTC tickers? Schwab?

 I've also heard of Interactive Brokers, TradeStation...  Any insight for a noob?

I'm finding some stuff here that *looks* like it has massive potential and very little risk. Maybe it's just because I have untrained eyes... But the fact I seem to be running into so many hurdles makes me feel like I'm right, and that **they** are just doing what they can to make it hard for the little man to get his piece of pie.

Help me out, and I will DM you with some of the tickers I'm looking at. Maybe you can confirm whether I'm a crazy gambling addict, or if I'm looking at potential for very attractive gains.

P.S. Some people probably want to tell me to be careful with penny stocks. Lots of risk, don't get addicted, all of that. I know the kind of person I am. I've got an itch and I have to scratch it. Maybe I'll get burned. Maybe I'll find some fat gains. Either way, I have to see for myself. I'm only working with several hundred dollars right now and even if I lose it *all*, I won't lose any sleep over it.

author: eclectictaste1
body:
Okay, serious answer. Longtime investor, since early 1990's. Started with monthly investments in SPY, VFIAX, QQQ, other Fidelity mutual funds offered through work 401k.  Early 2000's bought into FAANG's and others. Saw great returns in them, as expected. Pretty much ignored my investments other than 1 or 2 times/year when making IRA contributions and if I thought about it.

With market crash in 2020, plus older children interested in markets, I began investing/trading stocks which I thought would bounce back from lows, like MAR, HT, SVC, XOM, AAL, CCL.  Also, began swing trading SPY & QQQ options, with moderate success. Learned more about wheeling and options strategy. 

Recently began selling small portions of FAANG stocks, because they were overweighted in my portfolio, and because I don't think they will go 10x+ like they did in the 2000's. Just too big, not because they are badly run.  Better to find the new FAANG stocks, which could be EV's, weed, health care, China stocks, etc.

All money is staying in my investment accounts, I have other sources of income for day-to-day living, but will eventually use this money for kids' weddings, retirement home, life in retirement, unborn grandkids' college funds, etc. Generational wealth.

author: WallStLoser
body:
For the price of clean energy stuff to go up, you just need a greater fool, and those are in abundance. I like to gauge sentiment of the "apes" by looking at the top stocks traded on fidelity. 

  [Top Fidelity](https://eresearch.fidelity.com/eresearch/gotoBL/fidelityTopOrders.jhtml)  

You see all kinds of trash companies on there, and at the moment there are at least 5 EV or clean energy plays in this list. Many are junk companies that will go away.

If you look at Tesla, the hardest part has been manufacturing, and they still really aren't profitable on the actual cars. And if you look at the new mail truck, they talk about it being electric or not about "a choice of propulsion" and it's really not something that defines the vehicle. 

So much of the clean energy space is problematic because the problems they are trying to solve are hard problems and the laws of science aren't that generous sometimes. Look at the history and challenges of Hydrogen, it was not practical a decade ago and I'm pretty sure it's not practical now, it's too inefficient at scale. 

I've heard people say that people will buy EV's because it's the right thing to do. Yes, some people will, but they will only succeed in a big way if they are better at what they do an ICE vehicles. For some people they are, for most they are not.

author: Visible-Sherbet2621
body:
Realistically? No, and I'll be selling some to lock in gains even on the way up if/when it moons. But the fact I even think it's possible (and so do people like Thomas Petterfly) is worth holding onto a few shares, especially since like others I think this is a markedly different company with Cohen in charge.

There is a lot of evidence of potential catalysts in the next couple weeks, from the 3/19 option chains to the likely announcement of Cohen as CEO, and if you get some sort of gamma squeeze where the $800c's go ITM it should definitely hit that $5-10k per share price.

As for the last question the biggest difference this time around is that the $$$ isn't going from one hedge fund to retail, it's primarily hedge fund on hedge fund crime. Citadel is very connected politically, but so are Fidelity & BlackRock & Morgan Stanley etc...

On my wifes 403b, I can move money to a Schwab brokerage account, but they only allow you to buy from a list of mutual funds, not stocks or options.

author: wickedgames990
body:
Hey guys,

So my roth IRA for this year is maxed out.

My goal is to max my 401k ASAP.

But once that is done I'm planning to keep buying FSKAX in a fidelity individual taxable account. I'm not really one for holding multiple securities in one account, I just like to find one or two good reliable investments and put money into them.

Then next year I'll just repeat the process.

I figured that may be better than putting it into a savings account that isn't growing (I already have an emergency fund that can last me 6 months).

Thoughts on this? Are there better ways to be more efficient with investing my money?

&#x200B;

Edit: Some info:

25 y/o

not looking to use that money in the next 10 years (may possibly pull the money out of the individual brokerage account for something like a house)
